newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Monday said one percent of the corn crop was very poor, six percent poor, 25 percent fair, 50 percent good and 18 percent excellent.
Among the 17 major corn-producing states, 21 percent of the corn crop had silked, compared to 22 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 32 percent, USDA said.
In its report for the week ended July 20, USDA said the U.S. soybean crop was rated one percent very poor, seven percent poor, 30 percent fair, 51 percent good and 11 percent excellent.
USDA said 45 percent of the soybean crop was blooming, compared to 31 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 41 percent.
The department said two percent of the cotton crop was very poor, eight percent poor, 29 percent fair, 49 percent good and 12 percent excellent.
In spring wheat fields, three percent was rated very poor, 12 percent was poor, 33 percent was fair, 46 percent was good and six percent was excellent, USDA said.
Some 72 percent of the winter wheat crop was harvested, compared to 69 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 70 percent, USDA said.
